Description: Ring style oil-lamp; smallish closed form with small collar-like rim on top; low neat footring, convex bottom, shallow rounded sides, wide sloping shoulder. Tappering nozzle, rounded on top, merging with body. At rear, stumps of horizontal band handle on shoulder.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Locally produced variant of types found in Alexandria dated to the Late 4th or early 3rd century BC (Blondé 1998, 312-3, no. 1). See also contemporary parallels fopund in Italy and now in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, Q694 for handle, Q697 for rim and nozzle). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée d’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.56) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4839 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
